Introduction

Growing pains, also called "idiopathic nocturnal pains of childhood," are a common, benign cause of lower extremity (eg, thighs, calves) musculoskeletal pain in children.  The pain classically occurs at night and is self-limited, with no limitation in function or abnormality on examination.  The diagnosis is clinical, and the condition resolves by late childhood.

Etiology



Growing pains are the most common cause of intermittent musculoskeletal pain in children.  There is no known underlying cause, but potential contributing factors include a genetic predisposition and overuse.  Contrary to the name, the onset and location of the pain are unrelated to growth, and growing pains are sometimes referred to as "idiopathic nocturnal pains of childhood."

Clinical presentation



Growing pains are characterized by a nonprogressive aching sensation, primarily affecting the muscles of the lower extremities in children age 3-12.  The pain most commonly occurs bilaterally in the thighs, calves, and/or popliteal fossae but can less commonly manifest unilaterally or involve the upper extremities; the joints are not involved.



The pain usually arises in the evenings or overnight, awakening some children.  The degree of pain ranges from mild to severe, and it typically lasts from minutes to hours, resolving by morning; children can perform daily activities without limitation.  The pain is episodic, with pain-free days or weeks between episodes.  However, the pain is more likely to occur following significant physical activity, which may negatively impact a child's willingness to engage in such activities.



Physical examination of patients with growing pains is normal during and between episodes.

Differential diagnosis



Growing pains are a diagnosis of exclusion and must be differentiated from bone lesions, joint disorders, and other musculoskeletal conditions.  These diagnoses are usually associated with unilateral symptoms, systemic findings (eg, fever), and/or other pain features (eg, joint involvement, improvement with movement).



  • Juvenile idiopathic arthritis:  Patients have recurrent joint pain; fever and rash are seen in the systemic form.  Joint pain is classically worse in the morning and improves throughout the day.  Physical examination often shows joint stiffness and swelling.
  • Osteoid osteoma:  This benign, bone-forming tumor often involves the long bones (eg, femur, tibia), causing nocturnal pain relieved with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.  Symptoms are unilateral, and x-ray reveals a small, round lucency with a sclerotic margin and solid periosteal reaction (
    image 1
    ).
  • Osteosarcoma:  The most common primary bone malignancy classically presents with unilateral, focal pain (eg, long bone metaphysis) and a soft tissue mass.  X-ray reveals an ill-defined lesion with osteoblastic (radiodense) and osteolytic (radiolucent) areas and an aggressive periosteal reaction (eg, sunburst pattern) (
    image 2
    ).
  • Leukemia:  Leukemia can cause bilateral long bone pain.  However, the affected area is usually tender to palpation due to bone marrow expansion from leukemic cell infiltration.  In addition, most patients have systemic symptoms (eg, fever, weight loss) and other examination findings (eg, petechiae, splenomegaly).
  • Osteomyelitis:  Hematogenous spread of infection to the bone most frequently affects the long bones of the lower extremities in children.  Systemic symptoms (eg, fever, malaise) and persistent, unilateral pain that limits function would be expected.
  • Restless legs syndrome:  Patients experience dysesthesia (eg, crawling or itching sensation) and an irresistible urge to move the legs when at rest.  Symptoms occur primarily in the evenings and at night; they are partially relieved by movement.  The sensations of discomfort, rather than pain, and a desire to move the legs to alleviate the discomfort distinguish restless legs syndrome from growing pains.

Evaluation



Initial evaluation of any child with leg pain involves a thorough history and physical examination that focuses on the acuity and progression of symptoms, systemic findings (eg, fever, weight loss), and signs of joint inflammation (eg, edema, limp) (

).  Patients with these findings warrant evaluation (eg, complete blood count, inflammatory markers, x-ray).  Although unilateral symptoms can occur in growing pains, patients with unilateral pain warrant further work-up with imaging and/or laboratory evaluation.

Diagnosis



Growing pains are a diagnosis of exclusion based on the following:



  • Recurrent, self-limited episodes of bilateral, nocturnal limb pain in children age 3-12.
  • Normal physical examination (ie, no joint inflammation).
  • Absence of systemic findings (eg, fever) or progressive symptoms.

Management and prognosis



Growing pains may recur for months to years after onset and typically disappear by late childhood.  Short-term management includes reassurance and supportive care, including massage, heat, analgesics, or stretching exercises.  Although episodes may occur more frequently after increased daytime physical exertion, limitation of activity is not recommended.



There are no long-term complications of growing pains.

Summary



Growing pains (
